title.narrative: Arab Council for the Social Sciences 2013-2017
Arab Council for the Social Sciences 2013-2017

description.narrative: ACSS (Arab Council for the Social Sciences)är ett regionalt forskningsråd som arbetar för att stärka kapaciteten, räckvidden och påverkan av samhällsvetenskap i Arabvärlden. ACSS ämnar arbeta med att dela ut forskningsmedel, nätverka, kvalitetssäkring, och policy orienterat arbete.

ACSS is a regional social science research council. It works towards strengthening the capacity, quality, range and influence of the social sciences in the Arab region. As a research council it will support research grants, networks, quality assurance and policy oriented work.

participating-org.narrative: ACSS/Arab Council for the Social Sciences

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: In spite of the complexities of the MENA regional situation, the ACSS continued to grow in 2016 and was able to initiate new programmatic components.
The data gathered for the RBM logframe shows the greatest increase in results in the participation in conferences and in membership. The focus on junior scholars (post MA and PhDs with 7 years of experience) is notable, 74% of conference presenters belonging to this category. There has also been an increase in collaboration with regional and international networks which is reflected in disbursed travel grants, significantly with CODESRIA, CLACSO and SSRC-led Inter-Asia Partners. Another positive result reported 2016 was that 56% of ACSS grantees reported that their results were being used by non-academic users, such as in a policy context.
A drop is noted in the number of proposals received in the Research Grants Program. An analysis suggests that this is related to the introduction of a new theme which is rather specialised. On the other hand, the post-doctoral fellowships offered increased 230% in 2016, from from previously 22 to 61 applications.
The Palestine Focal Point started in 2015 has in 2016 stabilised, results being: organised focus group discussions at different universities; capacity building workshops; disseminated information regarding ACSS activities; and an annual forum discussing research agendas and perspectives specific to Palestine. The focal point serves as a model for planning other ACSS focal points in different countries, one being in Algeria pegged for 2017.
With regard to funding, 2016 included renewed funding from the Carnagie Corporation of New York. New grants were agreed with Ford Foundation, Mellon Foundation and UNESCO.
The ACSS organises a biennial conference and a biennial research conference on alternate years. 2016 the Algeria Research Forum took place, with 59 ACSS research grantees attending - despite great difficulties with visas. The Forum was an opportunity for the grantees to present, discuss and receive feedback on their ongoing research, as well as network, and have sessions on research methodologies, writing and publishing, research ethics and career opportunities.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
